Dear Mr. Hogue:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, Area Manager, at 616-552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
During an outing activity, a resident made sexual comments about other youth and
staff while at the beach. Resident would swim closer to a female resident and kick
her in the front genital area and buttocks.
2

INVESTIGATION:
On August 26, 2020 a special investigation was initiated into the allegation described
above. Staff and residents were interviewed. Documents were also reviewed. What
follows is information obtained from the aforementioned sources.
On August 27, 2020 a telephone call was initiated with the Michigan State Police
(MSP) Post in Negaunee. The MSP Sargent reported that the State Police will not
be investigating the alleged incident.
On August 27, 2020 emails were sent to the referring workers informing them of the
allegations and that an investigation has been initiated.
On August 27, 2020, Staff 1, the complainant in this case, was interviewed by
telephone and was interviewed a second time face to face on site on September 1,
2020. Staff 1 was interviewed a third time on October 21, 2020. Staff 1 offered the
following information. On August 13, 2020, he, another staff, and residents had
returned to the program from a recreational outing at a local beach. Resident A, the
alleged victim in this case, approached Staff 1 and informed him that another
resident, Resident B, had been talking about her ex - boyfriend and that she has sex
on her mind. Resident A informed Staff 1 that while in the water swimming Resident
B would lay back in the water and then kick Resident A in the buttocks or vaginal
area. Staff 1 reported that he did not see the alleged incident. Staff 1 reported that
when at the beach, at one point, Resident A and B were moving too far out in the
water and away from the beach so he went out into the water to supervise and
return Resident A and B closer to the beach. Staff 1 reported that Resident A and B
needed to be closer to staff in order to appropriately supervise the residents. Later in
the evening Staff 1 reported that he put the information received from Resident A
into the shift log book and recommended that Resident A and B should be closely
monitored while swimming at the beach. Staff 1 reported that he then sent the shift
notes to the agency social workers. Staff 1 was asked why he did not report the
alleged incident to central intake until August 26, 2020. Staff 1 stated that he later
realized that it was a mistake not to do so. Staff 1 stated that he reported the
incident when Staff 2, a Lead Direct Care Worker, who told him that he needed to
report the incident to Central Intake.
On September 1, 2020, Staff 3, a Direct Care Worker was interviewed. Staff 3
reported that he was a staff person, along with Staff 1, who was supervising
residents at the beach outing on August 13, 2020. Staff 3 reported that he did not
see anything inappropriate occurring between Resident A, B and C during the
outing.
On September 1, 2020, Resident A, a 13 year old female, was interviewed. Resident
A reported that while on an outing at the beach she and Resident B were swimming.
Resident A reported that one time Resident B went underwater and grabbed her
3

private parts and her legs. Resident A reported she told Staff 1 about it later in the
evening.
On September 1, 2020, Resident B, a 16 year old female, was interviewed. Resident
B denied that she had purposely kicked Resident A or Resident C in their buttocks or
private parts. Resident B denied going underwater and touching the buttocks or
private parts of Resident A.
On September 1, 2020, Resident C, a 12 year old female, was interviewed. Resident
C reported that while swimming at the lake Resident B would lay on her back as if
she was to swim on her back and when kicking her legs to stay afloat she kicked her
in the buttocks and genital area. Resident C reported that Resident B kicked her a
few times in this manner. Resident C reported that Resident B was doing this on
purpose.
In discussion with Resident C’s foster care worker she has reported Resident C is
highly sexualized, manipulative, and known to make false accusations of sexual
contact.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
The agency program shift notes for August 13, 2020 and written by Staff 1 were
reviewed. The notes indicate that Staff 1 went out into the water to provide
supervision when Resident A, B, and C were drifting farther away from the beach.
The shift notes suggest that staff wear bathing suits to the beach so staff can be in
the water with residents.
The files of Resident A, B, and C were reviewed.
A review of staff schedule and resident census for the program on August 13, 2020
was reviewed.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
4

ANALYSIS: Resident A and C reported that they were touched by Resident
B while swimming. Resident B denied touching either Resident
A or C in any inappropriate manner. Resident C is known to
make false allegations of sexual contact. Staff 1 and 3 did not
witness the alleged touching. Staff 1 entered the water to
provide appropriate supervision when the residents began
drifting further from the beach.
The agency was in the required staff to resident ratio while on
the outing. There were two staff to 4 residents.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Investigation 1:
During the course of this investigation Staff 1 and Staff 4 were asked if an incident
report was generated regarding the alleged sexual contact between the residents.
Staff 1 and Staff 4 stated that an incident report was not generated.
Document Review: A review of an agency policy titled “Critical Incident Reporting”,
“GH Policy 6L” requires that an incident report be generated when suspected sexual
touching has occurred.
Investigation 2:
On September 1, 2020, Staff 5, an agency Social Services Worker, was interviewed.
Staff 5 reported that he first heard of the incident on or about August 26, 2020, when
Staff 1 was filing the complaint. Staff 5 reported that he then initiated a safety plan
for Resident A. Staff 5 submitted the safety plan for my review. Staff 5 reported that
the safety plan for Resident A was the only one generated.
On September 1, 2020, Staff 6, an agency Social Services Worker, was interviewed.
Staff 6 reported that she did not know of the incident until todays date, September 1,
2020. Staff 6 is the worker for Resident B. Staff 6 stated she would have reported
the incident to central intake had she known about the allegations. Staff 6 also
stated that she was not aware of safety plans for Resident B. A safety plan does
exist for Resident C.
Document Review: A review of a safety plan for Resident A, dated August 28,
2020, indicates that safety protocols were initiated. A review of the file for Resident
5

C documents in a USP plan dated July 30, 2020, a safety plan for Resident C
regarding safe and appropriate boundaries with others.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
ANALYSIS: Investigation 1: Staff 1 and Staff 4 reported that an incident
report was not completed by the agency. A review of the agency
policy regarding incidents requires that the agency complete an
incident report. The agency failed to follow their policy as an
incident report was not completed.
Investigation 2: The safety plan for Resident A was initiated on
August 28, 2020, 15 days after the incident. The safety plan for
Resident A was developed late, which did not ensure her safety
for a period of 15 days.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
